SCIENCE

What happened at COP30? 4 science take-homes from the climate summit
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-11-25 16:34:08

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement Search author on: PubMed Google Scholar Search author on: PubMed Google Scholar COP30 left many countries disappointed because no new road maps were created to help nations transition away from fossil fuels.Credit: Wagner Meier/Getty Ten years after the Paris agreement was adopted, world leaders left the United Nations COP30 climate summit in Belém, Brazil, with an outcome that kept the process alive but does little to stave off the perils of global warming. Many scientists walked away dismayed and disappointed. Despite years of commitments and research that have laid the groundwork for action, the climate summit of achieved “essentially nothing”, says Johan Rockström, director of the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research in Germany. But, there were some signs of hope that multilateralism can tackle climate change. Over the course of two weeks, representatives from nearly 200 governments worked through hot days, long nights, a fire in the venue and numerous protests — including by Indigenous groups and others fighting for the protection of the Amazon and other tropical forests. Heatwaves linked to emissions of individual fossil-fuel and cement producers Heatwaves linked to emissions of individual fossil-fuel and cement producers In the end, governments agreed to a package of measures that pushes forward discussions on financial aid and a new ‘just transition' mechanism designed to ensure a fair and equitable shift from fossil fuels to clean energy. A glaring omission was language calling for the creation of road maps to phase out fossil fuels and halt deforestation, but Brazil has announced it will push those ideas forward independently of the COP process. Here, Nature takes a look at the results from COP30 and what comes next. The summit failed to deliver major new pledges to curb greenhouse-gas emissions. Out of the 194 entities and countries that sent representatives to COP30, roughly 80 didn't submit new commitments for 2035, as required under the accord, and the rest submitted weak pledges that are unlikely to alter global trajectory. As a result, scientists with the Climate Action Tracker consortium still project that the world is on track for upwards of 2.6 ° C of warming by 2100. “The new commitments don't even move the needle,” says Niklas Höhne, a climate-policy researcher at the NewClimate Institute, an environmental think tank based in Berlin. “It's really a sign that countries have limited appetite to support something more ambitious on climate.” Fossil fuels took centre stage briefly. More than 80 countries joined Brazil's President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in the call for the creation of a road map to phase out fossil fuels, but the proposal ultimately foundered after reported opposition from oil-producing nations including Saudi Arabia and others. But the idea isn't dead yet. Brazil promised to push forwards with it independently of the COP process, while the governments of Colombia and the Netherlands announced that they would host the first global conference on the just transition away from fossil fuels in April next year. Protesters carrying signs that read “our forests are not for sale” broke through security lines of the COP30 climate talks on 12 November.Credit: Pablo Porciuncula/AFP via Getty One of the largest disputes at the summit was who should pay for climate action and help developing nations to prepare for and adapt to the unavoidable impacts of global warming. Progress was made: wealthier nations committed to tripling the amount of money they provide to help low-income countries tackle global warming — to US$300 billion annually by 2035. The agreement also carries forward a broader goal of boosting the total to $1.3 trillion annually from all sources, including private investments. But questions remain about how this will be financed. Previous deals on climate action have been plagued by delays in achieving financial goals as well as by disagreements about how much money should come from publicly funded grants, as opposed to loans and private investments. China pledges to cut emissions by 2035: what does that mean for the climate? China pledges to cut emissions by 2035: what does that mean for the climate? The final deal at COP30 lays out a process to clarify these issues over the next two years. It's a step towards ensuring that wealthy countries meet their responsibilities to provide climate finance to those in need, says Jodi-Ann Wang, who researches equity and climate finance at the London School of Economics and Political Science. or doi: https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-025-03802-1 Reprints and permissions Brazil must beef up its COP30 scheme to preserve tropical forests Brazil's COP30 legacy should be to protect more of its forests Heatwaves linked to emissions of individual fossil-fuel and cement producers Read the paper: Achieving net zero greenhouse gas emissions critical to limit climate tipping risks How nitrogen compounds in fertilizers and fossil-fuel emissions affect global warming China pledges to cut emissions by 2035: what does that mean for the climate? Heatwaves linked to carbon emissions from specific companies Heatwaves linked to carbon emissions from specific companies Don't scrap climate COPs, reform them World View 25 NOV 25 For real climate action, empower women World View 11 NOV 25 Nanotyrannus and Tyrannosaurus coexisted at the close of the Cretaceous Article 30 OCT 25 Don't scrap climate COPs, reform them World View 25 NOV 25 World leaders must find the courage to end the fossil-fuel age Editorial 25 NOV 25 Standing up for Inuit-led research in Canada's changing Arctic Spotlight 19 NOV 25 World leaders must find the courage to end the fossil-fuel age Editorial 25 NOV 25 Don't scrap climate COPs, reform them World View 25 NOV 25 Standing up for Inuit-led research in Canada's changing Arctic Spotlight 19 NOV 25 Join ITM Strasbourg as a tenure-track PI advancing AI-powered translational research in fibrosis, cancer, and therapeutic target discovery. Intitute for Translational Medicine and Liver Disease, Inserm U1110 Thomas Baumert We seek researchers with a high impact in disciplines such as space science, marine science, AI, BCIs, flexible electronics, or neuroscience. Dongxiang Road, Chang'an District, Xi'an Shaanxi,710129, P.R.China. WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Tiny Yellowstone quakes ignite a surge of hidden life underground
Source: ScienceDaily    Published: 2025-11-25 14:14:40

Eric Boyd and his research team investigated how a burst of small earthquakes in 2021 affected the communities of microbes living deep beneath the Yellowstone Plateau Volcanic Field. These microbes inhabit rock and water systems far below the surface, where sunlight never reaches. Instead of relying on photosynthesis, they depend on chemical reactions that occur when water moves through fractured rock. This chemistry provides the energy that supports many forms of underground life. Earthquakes have the potential to reshape this environment in several ways. Shaking can break open new rock surfaces, force out fluids that were previously sealed away, and redirect the flow of water through the subsurface. Each of these effects can create fresh chemical reactions, which in turn alter the types of energy available to microbial communities. The authors refer to this shift in available resources as a change in the chemical "menu" that microbes can draw from. Sampling Yellowstone's Deep Fluids After the Quake Swarm To understand how seismic activity influenced this hidden ecosystem, the researchers collected water samples from a nearly 100-meter deep borehole located along the western edge of Yellowstone Lake. They sampled the site five times throughout 2021, giving them a rare look at how conditions changed both immediately and over the following months. Analyses of these samples showed notable increases in hydrogen, sulfide, and dissolved organic carbon after the earthquakes. These compounds serve as important energy sources for many subsurface organisms. As the chemistry of the water shifted, the team also detected a rise in planktonic cells, suggesting that more microbes were present in the water column than before. This combination of chemical and biological changes indicates that the quake swarm temporarily boosted the resources available to deep microbial life. Microbial Communities in Motion Beyond detecting an increase in cell numbers, Boyd and colleagues observed that the types of microbes present changed over time. This result stands out because subsurface microbial communities in continental bedrock aquifers are often considered relatively stable. In contrast, the Yellowstone system appeared to respond quickly and noticeably to the pulse of seismic energy. According to the authors, the kinetic energy associated with earthquakes can influence both the chemistry and the biological makeup of aquifer fluids. Their findings imply that even small seismic events can drive meaningful ecological shifts underground. Implications for Other Worlds With Rock and Water The processes observed in the Yellowstone borehole may not be unique. Many regions around the world experience regular seismic activity that could similarly reshape subsurface energy supplies. If this mechanism is widespread, it could help explain how microbial life persists in deep and isolated environments. The team also notes that the same basic dynamics might occur on other rocky planets that contain water. If earthquakes or similar geological motions can refresh chemical resources below the surface, this could expand the possible habitats for microbes on worlds such as Mars. Story Source: Materials provided by PNAS Nexus. Note: Content may be edited for style and length. Have any problems using the site? Questions?
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Scientists Want to Use One of the Most Dangerous Volcanoes in the U.S. to Power Our Future
Source: Popular Mechanics    Published: 2025-11-25 13:30:00

The Newberry Volcano south of Bend, Oregon, is the source of superhot rocks capable of producing electricity. Here's what you'll learn when you read this story: The planet is a roiling ball of geothermal energy, but so far, the U.S. hasn't been great at tapping into this near limitless energy source. According to the U.S. Energy Information Administration, the country has geothermal plants located in only seven states—all out west—producing roughly 0.4 percent (17 billion kilowatt-hours) of utility-scale electricity generation as of 2023. However, it doesn't take much imagination to see the untapped potential of geothermal energy. Iceland, for example, generates more than one-fourth of its electricity needs from geothermal energy directly. In an effort to tap into that potential, a start-up called Mazama Energy, is focusing its sights on Newberry Volcano, a large, active, shield volcano located roughly 20 miles south of Bend, Oregon. While not as well known as other Cascade volcanoes, such a Mount St. Helens, Mount Rainier, or even Mount Hood, Newberry is the largest volcano in the Cascade Volcanic Range, and the United States Geological Survey considers it a “very high threat” volcano, similar to Mauna Loa and Kīlauea in Hawaii. However, mixed within that danger is also an unprecedented geothermal opportunity. The reason why so many geothermal projects lie out west is because these super-heated resources lie much closer to the surface than in the eastern U.S. For the past 50 years, the area around Newberry Volcano has been explored for geothermal opportunities, but the startup Mazama Energy is using a technique known as “superhot rock.” Typical geothermal sites represent a perfect alignment of hot rock and water, which can produce steam that powers turbines. With superhot rock, on the other hand, energy companies inject water into areas with dry superheated rock at tempratures that are preferably over the threshold of 705 degrees Fahrenheit. At this temperature, and also under a lot of pressure, water becomes supercritical and begins acting like a mix of a liquid and gas. According to The Washington Post, this supercritical water can hold more heat like a liquid but flow like a gas, providing five to ten times more energy than typical geothermal operations. “The [liquid] water is Clark Kent when it goes down,” Sriram Vasantharajan, Mazama's CEO, told The Washington Post. “Then it gets heated, and when it comes up, it's Superman.” Similar to Mazama Energy's plans in Oregon, a 2024 report from the Bureau of Economic Geology (BEG) at the University of Texas at Austin similarly found that injecting water into superhot rock near the town of Presidio in southwestern Texas could provide a significant amount of electricity. In fact, according to a model produced by the Clean Air Task Force, 20 percent of the U.S.'s landmass, or around 750 thousand square miles, has superhot rock energy potential. But this energy doesn't come without risks, the biggest of which being man-made earthquakes. Fracking for natural gas is known to cause tremors by changing pressure conditions along faults, and in 2018, South Korea experienced its second most-powerful earthquake in modern history due to a geothermal plant. These risks can be managed with robust monitoring and engineering, and additionally, pollution isn't an issue since water recirculates in sealed wells and at distances below most groundwater reservoirs. Mazama Energy still needs to face the daunting task of keeping drilling and energy-producing infrastructure running under such punishing conditions, but the company tells The Washington Post they hope to produce 15 megawatts of electricity on Newberry Volcano's western flank by next year, and eventually pump out as much as 200 megawatts, roughly the energy budget of a small city. However, those numbers are small in comparison to the site's theoretical potential, which could be as high as five gigawatts, according to Vasantharajan—roughly two-thirds of Oregon's average energy output. Those geothermal aspirations, however, currently remain out of reach, but the U.S. hopes for geothermal to provide 16 percent of the country's energy mix by 2050. If it has any hope of achieving that dream, superhot rocks could be the key reason why. Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Get the Issue Darren lives in Portland, has a cat, and writes/edits about sci-fi and how our world works. You can find his previous stuff at Gizmodo and Paste if you look hard enough. All Rights Reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Which Pie Gives You the Biggest Sugar Rush: Pecan, Apple or Pumpkin?
Source: Scientific American    Published: 2025-11-25 13:00:00

November 25, 2025 4 min read Which Pie Gives You the Biggest Sugar Rush: Pecan, Apple or Pumpkin? Scientific American asked experts which type of Thanksgiving pie spikes blood sugar the most—and how to eat healthier while still enjoying the holidays By Tanya Lewis edited by Jeanna Bryner Jonathan Wiggs/The Boston Globe via Getty Images I love a good pie. Every year for Thanksgiving I make a bourbon chocolate pecan pie, which is every bit as decadent—and delicious—as it sounds. But it contains an ungodly amount of corn syrup and sugar, so it got me thinking: Which type of pie spikes your blood sugar the fastest? And is there a “healthier” pie? Pie varieties abound, so I focused on some of the classics: pecan, pumpkin and apple. Regardless of filling, when you take a bite of pie, the carbohydrates get delivered to your bloodstream as glucose that ultimately gets absorbed by cells. The faster those sugars get into your bloodstream, the quicker you experience a sugar rush. Any guesses on which pie would shuttle the most sugars the quickest? To get to the bottom of this gooey puzzle, I talked to Sarah Berry, a professor of nutritional sciences at Kings College London, and Sandra Arévalo, director of community health and wellness at Montefiore Nyack Hospital. If you're enjoying this article, consider supporting our award-winning journalism by subscribing. By purchasing a subscription you are helping to ensure the future of impactful stories about the discoveries and ideas shaping our world today. Here's how the different pies really stack up, according to the experts: Not all pies are created equally: you have more control over the ingredients in homemade pies, so they tend to be healthier than store-bought ones. In general, though, many pecan pies are on the sweeter side. “If we think of the average apple, pecan or pumpkin pie, on average, the pecan tends to be higher in sugar, followed by the pumpkin, followed by the apple pie,” Berry says. “But what we also know is the pecan tends to be higher in protein as well and tends to be a little bit higher in fiber.” So even though pecan pie is high in sugar, the protein and fiber slow down stomach emptying and, in turn, the release of glucose into the bloodstream. Protein also stimulates the release of the hormone insulin, which moves sugar into your cells and out of your bloodstream, Berry says. (Score one point for pecan pie!) But because pecans aren't that sweet, people often add a lot of sugar, Arévalo says. If you're making the pie at home, you can add less sugar or corn syrup. Pecan pie recipes often have corn syrup in them not only for the sweetness but for the texture, she says. So you could reduce the amount of corn syrup and replace it with chia seeds, for example. Another option for slowing the sugar rush in pecan pie is to serve it with a scoop of plain yogurt or some unsweetened cream, Berry and Arévalo suggest. Pumpkin pie generally contains less sugar and more dietary fiber than pecan. “Pumpkin is pretty sweet already,” Arévalo says, “so you might not need to add as much sugar. It has a little fiber, but it has zero protein.” Here again, you could serve the pie with some plain yogurt or even some nuts on top for a little extra protein. Nuts also give the pie some crunch, she says. Of the three pies mentioned, apple pie generally contains the least sugar and most fiber. “The more fruit it has, the better. The less sugar it has, the better. The more protein and fiber, the better,” Arévalo says. Still, “there's huge variability from one shop-bought apple pie to another shop-bought apple pie to a homemade apple pie,” Berry notes. If you're making the pie at home, you can use less sugar, and you can also make a whole-grain crust for the fiber, she says. For the filling, Arévalo recommends using apples with their fiber-rich peels on. Overall there's not a huge difference in the fiber or protein content of all three pies, Berry says. “So if I was going to have to opt for the lowest sugar—the pie that's going to increase my sugar the least—I'd probably say apple pie,” she says. Arévalo agrees: “Apple pie, I will say, looking at the glycemic load of all of these.” Glycemic load is a measure of how a given food affects blood sugar. As mentioned already, pecan pies tend to pack the most powerful punch, sugar-wise, and pumpkin pie isn't necessarily any better. But apple pie isn't always the healthier option here. “If the pecan pie doesn't have a lot of sugar, then I will put pecan pie first. It really depends on how sweet it is,” Arévalo says. You can make any homemade pie healthier by adjusting the amount of sugar, protein and fiber. And there are other ways to offset the effects of your pie consumption by taking a brisk walk after dessert. Eating breakfast and snacking on protein and fiber throughout the day can help prepare your body for the big meal and prevent a gigantic sugar spike. Ultimately, you should just enjoy your Thanksgiving feast. “At the end of the day, Thanksgiving is there for joy, for family, for connection, and the food that you eat should bring you joy,” Berry says. “If you enjoyed the pecan and the pumpkin and the apple, and you want lots of sugar in it, I wouldn't worry about it, personally.” Tanya Lewis is senior desk editor for health and medicine at Scientific American. She writes and edits stories for the website and print magazine on topics ranging from COVID to organ transplants. She also appears on Scientific American's podcast Science Quickly and writes Scientific American's weekly Health & Medicine newsletter. She has held a number of positions over her nine years at Scientific American, including health editor, assistant news editor and associate editor at Scientific American Mind. Previously, she has written for outlets that include Insider, Wired, Science News and others. She has a degree in biomedical engineering from Brown University and one in science communication from the University of California, Santa Cruz. Follow her on Bluesky @tanyalewis.bsky.social If you enjoyed this article, I'd like to ask for your support. Scientific American has served as an advocate for science and industry for 180 years, and right now may be the most critical moment in that two-century history. I've been a Scientific American subscriber since I was 12 years old, and it helped shape the way I look at the world. SciAm always educates and delights me, and inspires a sense of awe for our vast, beautiful universe. I hope it does that for you, too. In return, you get essential news, captivating podcasts, brilliant infographics, can't-miss newsletters, must-watch videos, challenging games, and the science world's best writing and reporting. This Fossil Is Rewriting the Story of How Plants Spread across the Planet
Source: Scientific American    Published: 2025-11-25 11:30:00

November 25, 2025 3 min read This Fossil Is Rewriting the Story of How Plants Spread across the Planet An enigmatic group of fossil organisms has finally been identified—and is changing the story of how plants took root on land By Taylor Mitchell Brown edited by Andrea Thompson An artistic reconstruction of Spongiophyton during the Early Devonian in the Paraná Basin. J. Lacerda/From "The rise of lichens during the colonization of terrestrial environments" by Bruno Becker-Kerber, et al., in Science Advances, Vol. 11, No. 44; October 29, 2025 Join Our Community of Science Lovers! Around 410 million years ago, terrestrial life was relatively simple. There were no forests or prairies—land was largely dominated by slimy microbial mats. The types of plants that would eventually give rise to trees and flowers had only just evolved and would take another several million years to fully flourish and diversify. A new discovery is rewriting the story of how these vascular plants, as they are called, spread onto land. Researchers may have finally resolved a debate about an enigmatic but widespread fossil called Spongiophyton: it seems to have been a strange life-form called a lichen that may have helped pave the way for plants to thrive on land. Fragment isolated from the stem of Spongiophyton nanum showing its upper surface with pores. From "The rise of lichens during the colonization of terrestrial environments" by Bruno Becker-Kerber, et al., in Science Advances, Vol. 11, No. 44; October 29, 2025 If you're enjoying this article, consider supporting our award-winning journalism by subscribing. By purchasing a subscription you are helping to ensure the future of impactful stories about the discoveries and ideas shaping our world today. The discovery, published recently in Science Advances, “settles a question that had been open for over a century,” says paleontologist Geovane Gaia, of the Institute of Geosciences at the State University of Campinas in Brazil, who was not involved with the research. “Until now, most people thought lichens appeared only after vascular plants, but this study shows they were already there at the beginning, literally helping prepare the ground for plant life.” Lichens are the symbiotic result of fungi and photosynthetic algae or cyanobacteria working together. Today that amalgam helps churn lifeless rocks and sediments into nutrient-rich soil everywhere from polar deserts to tropical forests, says study lead author Bruno Becker-Kerber, a paleontologist at Harvard University. Vascular plants have tissues that funnel those soil nutrients from the ground to their stems and leaves. Because lichens' soft body tissues are rarely preserved in the fossil record, their origins have remained mysterious. A 2019 genetic analysis suggested they evolved well after the emergence of vascular plants, indicating they likely played little to no role in early land colonization. Scientists have long debated whether Spongiophyton, which flourished around 410 million years ago, was lichen or algae. To determine the fossils' identity, Becker-Kerber and his colleagues analyzed the underlying chemical properties of lingering organic material within the fossils. Unlike algae, which are lined with cell walls, lichen contain fungi lined with chitin, the same material that makes up the exoskeletons of insects. Chitin is loaded with nitrogen, and the team's results turned up an unmistakable nitrogen signal. “The more we tested it, the more consistent the signal became,” Becker-Kerber says. “It was genuinely exciting.” There were other fungal traits present, too, such as a distinct branching pattern exhibited by growing fungal cells called hyphae. The results suggest lichen evolved around 410 million years ago, shortly after the initial spread of vascular plants 420 million years ago and just before the earliest known forests around 390 million years ago. “It's a major shift in how we view the complexity of life's first steps onto land,” Becker-Kerber says. Spongiophyton “likely weathered rocks, stabilized sediments, cycled nutrients and contributed to the formation of protosoils just before forests developed.” “If Spongiophyton was a lichen, it may have enabled the expansion of land plants into areas previously uncolonized,” says Matthew Nelsen, an evolutionary biologist at the Field Museum of Natural History, who was not involved with the research. The new picture suggests lichen emerged near the beginning of terrestrial plant history and the unique fungi-algae relationship may have been essential to the spread of plants. “People often tell the story of life's move onto land as a ‘plant story,'” Becker-Kerber says. “What our study shows is that fungi and lichens were also part of it.” Taylor Mitchell Brown is a San Diego–based journalist covering anthropology and paleontology, with occasional forays into other disciplines. You can find him in Science, Science News, New Scientist, National Geographic, Scientific American, and elsewhere. Read his latest musings on Bluesky: @tmitchellbrown.bsky.social If you enjoyed this article, I'd like to ask for your support. Scientific American has served as an advocate for science and industry for 180 years, and right now may be the most critical moment in that two-century history. I've been a Scientific American subscriber since I was 12 years old, and it helped shape the way I look at the world. SciAm always educates and delights me, and inspires a sense of awe for our vast, beautiful universe. I hope it does that for you, too. If you subscribe to Scientific American, you help ensure that our coverage is centered on meaningful research and discovery; that we have the resources to report on the decisions that threaten labs across the U.S.; and that we support both budding and working scientists at a time when the value of science itself too often goes unrecognized. In return, you get essential news, captivating podcasts, brilliant infographics, can't-miss newsletters, must-watch videos, challenging games, and the science world's best writing and reporting. You can even gift someone a subscription. There has never been a more important time for us to stand up and show why science matters. I hope you'll support us in that mission. Thank you, David M. Ewalt, Editor in Chief, Scientific American Subscribe to Scientific American to learn and share the most exciting discoveries, innovations and ideas shaping our world today. Scientific American is part of Springer Nature, which owns or has commercial relations with thousands of scientific publications (many of them can be found at www.springernature.com/us). Scientific American maintains a strict policy of editorial independence in reporting developments in science to our readers. © 2025 SCIENTIFIC AMERICAN, A DIVISION OF SPRINGER NATURE AMERICA, INC.ALL RIGHTS RESERVED.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Charting the influence of deuterium sources in hydrogen isotope exchange using a cobalt(III) catalytic platform
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-11-25 10:59:42

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement Nature Catalysis (2025)Cite this article A preprint version of the article is available at ChemRxiv. Directed hydrogen isotope exchange strategies have become an essential tool for accessing isotopically labelled organic scaffolds and interrogating the mechanisms of transition metal-catalysed C–H activation. However, the rationale behind deuterium source selection remains largely absent from the literature; an oversight that directly affects mechanistic interrogation strategies and hinders the development of new deuteration methodologies. Here we explore the influence of the deuterium source in base-assisted site-selective C–H deuteration reactions across a broad range of substrates using cobalt catalysis. We employ a synergistic combination of experimental studies and multivariable linear regression models based on proposed catalytic intermediates. Our findings demonstrate that the deuterium source can directly alter the operative mechanism, leading to distinct reaction pathways under different conditions. These results highlight previously overlooked complexity in hydrogen isotope exchange reactions and provide an example of how data-driven mechanistic analysis can expose subtle, reagent-dependent mechanistic shifts in catalytic behaviour. Transition metal-catalysed hydrogen isotope exchange (HIE) bridges fundamental research and practical synthetic utility1,2,3,4,5. These reactions serve both as a mechanistic probe for studying the reversibility of C–H activation, and as an effective methodology for introducing isotopic labels into molecules relevant to medicinal chemistry6,7,8. Nevertheless, an elusive aspect of HIE is the suitability of a given deuterium source for a specific transformation. Even a close examination of the literature within the vibrant field of directed, base-assisted C–H activation, reveals an assortment of isotope sources across transition metal catalysis (Fig. 1a and Supplementary Table 1). This ambiguity led us to question whether hidden behind this deceptively simple transformation was a common yet overlooked pitfall—different combinations of conditions and substrates can trigger distinct mechanistic pathways. a, Challenges and opportunities. The literature search for papers involving directed HIE was performed using SciFinder in March 2025 (Supplementary Table 1). b, Synergistic combination of experimental studies and MLR models based on proposed catalytic intermediates to uncover the influence of deuterium sources in HIE (this work). DG, directing group. Most experimental or computational mechanistic approaches are predominantly geared to explore the mechanism of a reaction using a model substrate9,10,11,12,13. However, we sought to develop an approach that could shed light on complex mechanistic landscapes forged by changes to substrates and reaction conditions. To this end, we turned our attention to linear free energy relationship (LFER) studies, which follow the influence of substituent effects on a reaction outcome14. The underlying assumption behind LFER is that as long as substrates follow a similar mechanistic route, a linear correlation can be identified between a molecular descriptor (for example, Hammett electronic values or Tolman cone angles) and the reaction outcome (for example, the yield or selectivity)15,16. In recent years, this idea has been extended to multivariable linear regression (MLR), wherein several molecular descriptors are required to describe the factors that influence a reaction outcome17,18,19,20,21,22,23,24. Whereas descriptors are most often drawn from the structural properties of starting materials, in some cases meaningful correlations only emerge when features of key reaction intermediates are included25,26,27,28,29,30,31. Motivated by the idea that molecular descriptors from different reaction intermediates can more faithfully capture substrate behaviour in distinct reaction manifolds, we envisioned a strategy to explicitly evaluate divergent mechanistic pathways. On the basis of this premise, in this work, we uncover mechanistically relevant pathways by analysing correlations between descriptors from different plausible intermediates and the reaction outcome (Fig. 1b). Namely, we seek to ask whether multiple mechanisms could be operative in HIE using the most common inexpensive and convenient deuterium sources, such as D2O, CD3OD or AcOD-d4. Our approach, rooted in the comparison of reaction intermediates, reveals a complex yet strong relationship between the substrate structure and the required deuterium source, revealing patterns inaccessible by intuition alone. These findings suggest that the isotope source can act as a mechanistic trigger, eliciting distinct pathways depending on the substrate structure. We initiated our investigation by establishing a catalytic platform tailored to uncover the factors that govern hydrogen isotope exchange. Cp*CoIII complexes were chosen as an ideal model because they operate through a reversible C–H activation step32,33,34, enabling efficient H/D exchange across a wide array of directing groups and multiple deuterium sources35,36,37,38,39. We then evaluated its suitability for isotopic labelling using different deuterium sources on diverse scaffolds (Fig. 2). To this end, we targeted the following widely used directed C–H functionalization substrates, 2-phenylpyridine (I), benzaldehyde (II) and acetanilide (III), and identified three optimized reaction conditions (Supplementary Tables 2–4). Both 2-phenylpyridine (I) and benzaldehyde (II) underwent efficient H/D exchange using D2O as the deuterium source (Conditions A and B, respectively). By contrast, CD3OD provided the highest levels of deuterium incorporation for acetanilide (III, Condition C). Deuterium incorporations were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy. aFor substrate II, we added aniline (20 mol%). To construct a diverse dataset for statistical analysis, we selected substrates that would have practical relevance but would also provide a broad distribution of structural diversity and deuteration levels (Fig. 3). Under Condition A, we examined a series of 2-phenylpyridine derivatives, observing a broad functional group tolerance for both electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents at the phenyl para position (2–4). Compounds 5 and 6, which contain additional coordinating functionalities, are deuterated only at the position ortho to the pyridine-directing group, which is consistent with the strong coordinating effect of N-containing heterocycles. Steric hindrance at the ortho position (7) did not strongly affect the outcome, and modifications to the pyridine ring itself (8–10) preserved reactivity. We also evaluated the late-stage deuteration of biologically relevant molecules. The pyridine-containing antiretroviral drug atazanavir (11) afforded high deuterium incorporation in excellent yield. Condition A: substrate (0.25 mmol), Cp*Co(CO)I2 (10 mol%), KOAc (20 mol%), AgSbF6 (20 mol%), D2O (25 equiv.), DCE (0.5 ml), 50 °C, 2 h. Condition B: substrate (0.25 mmol), Cp*Co(CO)I2 (10 mol%), Cu(OAc)2 (10 mol%), AgSbF6 (20 mol%), D2O (10 equiv.), DCE (2.5 ml), 100 °C, 2 h. Condition C: substrate (0.25 mmol), Cp*Co(CO)I2 (10 mol%), Cu(OAc)2 (10 mol%), AgSbF6 (20 mol%), CD3OD (10 equiv.), DCE (5 ml), 100 °C, 2 h. aReaction carried out at 0.1 mmol scale. bAniline (20 mol%) was added. cYield determined by 1H NMR of the reaction crude with 1,3,5-trimethoxybenzene as internal standard. For Condition B, we targeted aromatic aldehydes, using aniline as a transient directing group for in situ imine formation40,41. The transient role of aniline was confirmed by submitting the preformed imine of benzaldehyde (13), N-benzylideneaniline (12), to Condition B in the absence of aniline, which afforded the same deuterium incorporation as benzaldehyde. A diverse range of aromatic aldehydes were efficiently deuterated (13–26) under these conditions. Compound 20, which contains an aldehyde and pyridine group, was deuterated across all ortho positions. The same reactant under Condition A was uniquely deuterated at the positions ortho to pyridine (see compound 5). We note that the acetamido group of compound 19 did not facilitate isotope labelling and only the positions ortho to the aldehyde were deuterated. When 5-phenylthiophene-2-carbaldehyde (26) was subjected to Condition B, we only observed H/D exchange at the ortho positions of the carbonyl group, indicating that thiophene is not a suitable directing group under these conditions. Interestingly, in the absence of aniline, Condition B remained highly efficient for arenes containing strong N-based directing groups (substrates 27–46), which had shown limited reactivity under Condition A. These results include several pharmaceutically relevant heterocycles, such as pyrazoles and oxazoles, and the late-stage functionalization of the anti-inflammatory drug etoricoxib (45), as well as the arthritis medication oxaprozin (46). Finally, we examined the compatibility of Condition C with a variety of amide derivatives, which are prevalent in medicinal chemistry42. Acetanilides bearing electron-donating or electron-withdrawing moieties with different substitution patterns reached moderate to high degrees of deuterium incorporation (47–53). Sterically demanding groups connected to the carbonyl group proved to be beneficial for this transformation (54 and 55). A urea derivative (56) and monosubstituted amides (57 and 58) were compatible with our protocol. A clear decrease in deuterium incorporation was observed for disubstituted amides (59–62), but lactam 63, a cyclic disubstituted amide, afforded improved deuterium incorporation. Lastly, functional group compatibility was tested in selected biologically active molecules containing challenging moieties, such as hydroxy or carboxylic acid motifs (64 and 65). In agreement with our results, the necessity of using different deuterium sources is also widespread in the HIE literature1,2,3,4,5. However, there are no studies focused on uncovering the mechanistic implications of the deuterium source on a given organic scaffold in base-assisted C–H deuteration. Thus, we sought to apply MLR models to correlate the structural features of scaffolds with their corresponding deuterium incorporation values43,44,45. Initially, we attempted to produce models using molecular descriptors derived directly from substrate structures. However, these features led to poor correlations (Supplementary Fig. 3). As a result, we hypothesized that molecular descriptors produced from reaction intermediates could provide improved models and might better capture mechanistic distinctions between the tested condition sets (Fig. 4). The main setback towards extracting such molecular descriptors is the identification of catalytically relevant intermediates that could represent the mechanism of the studied reaction. a, Illustration of the most predictive MLR models identified for each condition. The linear graphs represent the correlation between the predicted and measured deuterium levels taken as \(\triangle \triangle G=\,-{RT}\log \left(\frac{ \% {\text{H}}}{ \% {\text{D}}}\right)\) to reflect the energy difference for obtaining each product with a 90% prediction interval in grey. Below each plot are the linear equations and the features identified to provide the best fit with the experimental outcomes. Each data point was sampled from a crude reaction performed in duplicates at a scale of 0.1 mmol. Proposed intermediates (Int) that were tested by MLR. Below each of the intermediates is a bar graph showing the goodness-of-fit R2 values (blue) and the leave-one-out (LOO) cross-validation Q2 values (orange) for all the intermediates (values given between 0.6 and 0.9, see Supplementary Figs. 31–33) in each one of the conditions. b, Comparison of the deuterium incorporation obtained with different deuterium sources for Conditions A, B and C. We viewed this challenge as an opportunity to develop a workflow based on sifting through correlations of features extracted from different plausible intermediates. This approach was based on the assumption at the crux of LFER studies that the best correlation with experimental results can enclose information regarding the relevant mechanistic pathway. By extending this assumption to reaction intermediates, we aimed to address a gap in the application of computational chemistry to tease out experimental mechanistic information. Whereas density functional theory (DFT) studies play a crucial role in revealing complete reaction pathways for a single model substrate, our approach provides a view of the reaction mechanism landscape through the prism of a broad set of substrates. In this work, to probe the potential involvement of different D shuttles under our reaction conditions, we selected several plausible intermediates to test on the basis of previous mechanistic proposals for directed base-assisted C–H activation46,47,48. Setting all the tested substrates in each of these intermediates, we performed ground-state DFT computations and extracted relevant molecular descriptors (Supplementary Figs. 4–30). A linear regression model search across the features of each of the seven proposed intermediates was conducted to identify the best-fitted correlation to the deuteration level in the three reaction condition sets (Fig. 4a). We note that for intermediates where ROD molecules participate, we computed both D2O and CD3OD options. For Condition A, a predictive model was identified based on intermediate Int5water, where acetic acid is directly coordinated to the metal and the deuterium source (D2O) bridges the D transfer through hydrogen bonding. The model reveals a tight correlation between deuterium incorporation and three molecular features: the partial charge on an acetic acid oxygen atom connected to the metal centre (q1), the overall dipole of the intermediate (μtot) and the minimal width of the substrate (Sterimol B1). According to the normalized regression coefficients the most impactful features are the charge and the total dipole of the intermediate, indicating that electronic effects probably play an important role in determining deuterium incorporation. In addition, all the features are localized on either the acetate or substrates, with the purely steric feature, B1, reflecting that the planarity of the substrates contributes to increasing deuterium incorporation. This model suggests that both acetic acid and water may be involved in the deuteration event in a cooperative deuterium transfer mechanism. When comparing the two models stemming from Int5 for the results of Condition A, the structure containing water provided a more robust model compared to the one with methanol (Int5water: R2 = 0.88, Q2LOO = 0.81; Int5methanol: R2 = 0.81, Q2LOO = 0.64). These outcomes are consistent with the experimental observation that D2O is a more effective deuterium source under Condition A (Supplementary Table 2). For Condition B, the model identified intermediate 3 (Int3water) as having the best fit with the experimental results. Similarly to the substrates under Condition A, we identified an improved fit for the intermediate containing water as a deuterium source, which, here too, agrees with the experimental results (Supplementary Table 3). The model reveals a correlation between deuterium incorporation and four molecular features: the partial charge on the hydrogen atom that bridges between water and acetate (q2), the difference in partial charge between the cobalt and the carbon undergoing deuteration (∆q3), the difference in partial charge between the water hydrogen atom and the oxygen of the acetate (∆q4) and the distance between the cobalt and directing group (d1). Here, similarly to Condition A, the features lean towards stronger electronic control of reactivity, with charge-related features being particularly dominant. The coefficients of the normalized model are all similar in magnitude and the features are localized to either the substrate or acetate, yet, unlike Condition A, here the substrate features seem to be more electronic in nature. Lastly, for Condition C, the model with the best fit to the experimental results was Int2, in which acetic acid is directly coordinated to the metal with no additional deuterium source included in the intermediate. The molecular features in this model include the partial charge on one of the ring carbons (q5), the overall dipole of the intermediate (μtot), the component of the dipole moment perpendicular to the benzene ring (μz) and the maximal width of the directing group (Sterimol B5). The normalized equation shows that μtot and Sterimol B5 are the most significant features, which indicates that this model leans toward steric control of deuterium incorporation compared with other conditions. Furthermore, the features are localized only on the substrates and not the acetate, unlike in Conditions A and B. In this model, the substrate is influenced by both steric and electronics features, and deuterium incorporation is increased when the width of the substrates' directing group is minimized and the dipole moment and charge on the substrate increase. In all three models, acetate or acetic acid is connected to the cobalt centre. However, for Conditions A and B, the best-fitting intermediates involve a well-orchestrated organization of the deuterium source, acetate/acetic acid and substrate around the metal centre. By contrast, the intermediate identified for Condition C, relies solely on acetic acid. Interestingly, Conditions A and B use water as their deuterium source, whereas Condition C requires methanol. Thus, the intermediates that correlate with the experimental results might imply that the primary role of water as a deuterium source is deuterium shuttling at the product-determining transition state, whereas methanol might have a distinct role. The superior performance of the model stemming from Int2 under Condition C, which only contains acetic acid, led us to speculate that methanol does not participate in the deuterodemetallation step, but rather facilitates a prior deuterium exchange. This proposal was supported by the fact that methanol's increased miscibility in dichloroethane (DCE) compared to water could endow it with the propensity to more easily transfer deuterium to acetate49. Indeed, under Condition C D2O leads to poor deuterium incorporation. To test the hypothesis that under Condition C acetic acid might be the effective deuterating agent, we conducted experiments using AcOD-d4 with model substrates under each of the reaction conditions (Fig. 4b and Supplementary Tables 7–9). Gratifyingly, for acetanilide under Condition C, AcOD-d4 led to the same deuterium incorporation as CD3OD, supporting our hypothesis that acetic acid is the effective deuterating agent. By contrast, for 2-phenylpyridine under Condition A, AcOD-d4 led to a significant decrease in deuterium incorporation compared to D2O. This result fits well with the suggested intermediate Int5water, which requires the presence of both acetic acid and water to react in concert. Further supporting this hypothesis is the decrease in deuterium incorporation levels when switching from D2O to AcOD-d4 for 1-phenyl pyrazole under Condition B, for which Int3water that contains both an acetate and water provided the best fit. Interestingly, this decrease under Condition B is much less pronounced compared to the decrease under Condition A. We turned to the correlated models to seek an explanation for this difference in outcomes and specifically to the correlations under each of these conditions with Int2, which only contained acetic acid. For Condition B the second best-fitted model corresponded to Int2 (R2 = 0.75, Q2LOO = 0.63), whereas for Condition A this intermediate provided a poor fit (R2 = 0.68, Q2LOO = 0.56; Supplementary Fig. 8). This result might suggest the existence of two competing pathways, which under Condition B are closer in energy and, therefore, could more easily be triggered by the presence of a different deuterium source. The work discussed here seeks to unlock the untapped potential of reaction intermediate descriptors to reveal hidden mechanistic structure–function relationships. This approach is complementary to insight garnered by DFT computations, which often provide a detailed account of the full reaction trajectory for a model substrate, but are seldom extended to multiple substrates and conditions. By integrating this approach with detailed experimental data from base-assisted directed HIE reactions, we demonstrate that beyond simple differences in deuterium incorporation levels, the choice of deuterium source might lead to a mechanistic shift, highlighting the need to treat deuterium sources with caution in mechanistic studies. Our analysis suggests that under Conditions A and B the deuterium source (D2O) participates directly in the deuteration step, whereas under Condition C isotope exchange with the deuterium source (CD3OD) probably occurs off-cycle. These mechanistic hypotheses were supported experimentally and illustrate the value of statistical models based on proposed reactive intermediates for uncovering hidden mechanistic complexity in catalytic reactions. Our findings reveal that the deuterium source can actively influence the reaction pathway, a factor that is critical for mechanistic interpretations, and which impacts reaction efficiency. Our work argues against assuming a single mechanistic pathway across substrates or metals and underscores the importance of evaluating multiple deuterium sources for each directing group. Furthermore, when employed in their non-deuterated form, these sources may mediate C–H bond cleavage when acting as solvents or additives. Therefore, the implications of this work extend beyond the specific catalytic system studied or HIE literature, as it reveals overlooked mechanistic distinctions that might be prevalent in organometallic catalysis. Deuterium incorporations were determined by 1H NMR using D1 = 1 s when taking aromatic signals as reference. For the two examples (59, 62) in which aliphatic signals need to be taken as reference, D1 = 50 s was used. Isolated yields were calculated taking into consideration the deuterium incorporation in the final product. Cross-validation of the deuterium incorporation with HRMS was performed in 13 selected examples across the three reaction conditions. Cp*Co(CO)I2 (11.9 mg, 0.025 mmol, 10 mol%) was charged into a 5 ml crimped vial and transferred to a glovebox, where KOAc (4.9 mg, 0.05 mmol, 20 mol%), AgSbF6 (17.2 mg, 0.05 mmol, 20 mol%), substrate (0.25 mmol, 1 equiv. (note: if the substrate is a liquid, it was added after the solvent)) and DCE (0.5 ml) were added. The vial was crimped, taken out of the glovebox and D2O (112 µl, 6.25 mmol, 25 equiv.) was added through the septum of the cap. The mixture was stirred for 2 hours at 50 °C. The crude was purified by column chromatography employing a AcOEt:hexane (1:1) mixture as eluent. Cp*Co(CO)I2 (11.9 mg, 0.025 mmol, 10 mol%) was charged into a 5 ml crimped vial and transferred to a glovebox, where Cu(OAc)2 (4.5 mg, 0.025 mmol, 10 mol%), AgSbF6 (17.2 mg, 0.05 mmol, 20 mol%), substrate (0.25 mmol, 1 equiv. (note: if the substrate is a liquid, it was added after the solvent)) and DCE (2.5 ml) were added. The vial was crimped, taken out of the glovebox and aniline (4.6 μl, 0.05 mmol, 20 mol% (note: only added for substrates that are aldehydes)) and D2O (45 μl, 2.5 mmol, 10 equiv.) were added through the septum of the cap. The mixture was stirred for 2 hours at 100 °C. The crude was purified by column chromatography employing a AcOEt:hexane (1:5) mixture as eluent. Cp*Co(CO)I2 (11.9 mg, 0.025 mmol, 10 mol%) was charged into a 5 ml crimped vial and transferred to a glovebox, where Cu(OAc)2 (4.5 mg, 0.025 mmol, 10 mol%), AgSbF6 (17.2 mg, 0.05 mmol, 20 mol%), substrate (0.25 mmol, 1 equiv. (note: if the substrate is a liquid, it was added after the solvent)) and DCE (5 ml) were added. The vial was crimped, taken out of the glovebox and CD3OD (102 μl, 2.5 mmol, 10 equiv.) was added through the septum of the cap. The mixture was stirred for 2 hours at 100 °C. The crude was filtered through a celite and silica pad. Deuterium incorporations were determined by 1H NMR spectroscopy of the crude. All substrates were modelled in a conformation directing the hydrogen and directing group in the same orientation. Substrates were computed using the M06-2X functional with the def2-TZVP basis set. Reaction intermediates were computed using the M06-2X functional with the 6-31g(d) basis set. For each intermediate, a set of computations was created, each time with a different substrate according to the experimental scope. After geometry optimization, features were extracted for each intermediate–substrate pair under each condition, and the resulting dataset was used to generate linear regression models. Feature extraction and modelling were performed using the moleculaR50 package in R. Further information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article. All data are available in the main text or Supplementary Information, or are available from the authors upon request. The datasets (in .csv format), .xyz files and the corresponding results are openly available via Zenodo at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.17086123 (ref. 51) and via GitHub at https://github.com/Milo-group/Deciphering_HIE_Multiple_Pathways.
